headline: Controversial Regulatory Standards Bill Passes Second Reading Amid Fierce Opposition
summary: Parliament was dominated by the advancement of two contentious government bills, with the Regulatory Standards Bill passing its second reading and a late amendment to remove Treaty of Waitangi obligations for school boards sparking heated debate. In Question Time, the government faced intense pressure from the Opposition over the cost of living crisis, highlighted by record-high KiwiSaver hardship withdrawals and a growing measles outbreak.

topicSummaries.topic: Regulatory Standards Bill Passes Second Reading
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This bill fundamentally changes how future laws are made, requiring governments to justify new regulations against a set of principles focused on property rights and individual liberty.
topicSummaries.content: The ACT Party's flagship Regulatory Standards Bill passed its second reading, supported by its National and New Zealand First coalition partners. Minister for Regulation David Seymour argued the bill would improve lawmaking quality by forcing politicians to justify regulations that restrict freedoms or impact property rights. Opposition parties fiercely opposed the bill, with Labour's Dr Duncan Webb calling it an ideological, poorly consulted piece of legislation that failed to meet its own standards. The Greens' Chlöe Swarbrick described it as a "pet vanity project" that prioritizes corporate interests over collective wellbeing and the environment, noting that over 98% of public submissions were in opposition.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon DAVID SEYMOUR (Minister for Regulation)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill turns the explanation from politicians passing laws that restrict our freedoms from 'Because we said so' into 'Because here is the justification, according to a set of principles.'

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr DUNCAN WEBB (Labour—Christchurch Central)
keyExchanges.quote: What did the New Zealand Law Society say? 'It is striking that the process and content of a Bill purporting to promote good law-making and high-quality legislation should fail to meet not only the Bill's own standards, but the existing established processes for supporting good law-making.'

topicSummaries.topic: Government Moves to Remove Treaty of Waitangi Clause for School Boards
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This proposed change shifts the legal responsibility for Treaty obligations from volunteer school boards directly to the Crown, fundamentally altering school governance focus.
topicSummaries.content: During debate on the Education and Training Amendment Bill, Education Minister Erica Stanford introduced a late amendment to remove the explicit requirement for school boards to "give effect to the Treaty of Waitangi." Minister Stanford argued this legal responsibility properly belongs to the Crown, not volunteer parents on boards, and that the change provides clearer objectives for boards to seek equitable outcomes for Māori students and provide for te reo Māori. The move drew strong condemnation from Opposition parties, who criticized the lack of consultation and argued it diminishes the Treaty's role in education. Labour's Willow-Jean Prime and Cushla Tangaere-Manuel questioned the Minister's understanding of the Crown's Treaty obligations and how they would be upheld without the clause.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon ERICA STANFORD (Minister of Education)
keyExchanges.quote: This Government does not believe that it is reasonable to expect these parents, who are, effectively, volunteers, to carry legal responsibilities that rightly belong to the Crown.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon WILLOW-JEAN PRIME (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: what gave the Minister the right to determine that Te Tiriti o Waitangi means providing resources in te reo Māori? Who gave the Minister and the Crown the sole right to determine that giving effect to Te Tiriti o Waitangi is to simply provide resources in te reo Māori?

topicSummaries.topic: Record KiwiSaver Hardship Withdrawals Dominate Question Time
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: A surge in people accessing their retirement savings for basic needs indicates significant, ongoing financial distress for many households.
topicSummaries.content: The Opposition used Question Time to challenge the government's economic narrative, focusing on record-high KiwiSaver hardship withdrawals. Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins noted that for the first time in a decade, hardship withdrawals have consistently outnumbered first-home withdrawals, which he attributed to rising costs for essentials like doctors' visits and transport under the current government. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon acknowledged the difficult economic period, blaming the previous government's spending, but insisted the economy was improving, citing positive indicators such as rising job ads and exports.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: Is he aware that under his leadership, hardship withdrawals from KiwiSaver have outnumbered first-home withdrawals from KiwiSaver month after month, when previously it only happened once in 10 years?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon CHRISTOPHER LUXON (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, as I said to the member in my answer to his first question, it has been a difficult time for the New Zealand economy. We inherited a recession that was probably the worst in 35 years.

topicSummaries.topic: Nationwide Immunisation Week Launched Amid Measles Outbreak
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: With measles cases confirmed in multiple regions, health officials are urging vaccination to prevent a large-scale outbreak that could strain hospitals and disrupt schools.
topicSummaries.content: In response to a growing measles outbreak, Health Minister Simeon Brown announced the launch of a nationwide Measles Immunisation Week. During Question Time, Brown stated that cases were confirmed across multiple regions and the risk of transmission is high. He credited the reintroduction of health targets for an increase in childhood immunisation rates for two-year-olds to 82%, up from 76.5% last year. However, he acknowledged this is still well below the 95% coverage needed to stop future outbreaks. Labour's Health spokesperson, Dr Ayesha Verrall, challenged the Minister, questioning whether the risk of an outbreak was still growing as the number of susceptible people continues to increase each month.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon SIMEON BROWN (Minister of Health)
keyExchanges.quote: Our Government is taking the current measles outbreak very seriously. Cases are now confirmed across multiple regions, and the risk of continued transmission is high.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Ayesha Verrall (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Is it correct that despite his Government's performance against the target, the number of susceptible people is estimated to increase by a thousand a month and, therefore, the risk of an outbreak continues to grow irrespective of the target?

conclusion: The Government successfully advanced its controversial legislative agenda on regulation and education, while the Opposition relentlessly focused on the immediate economic pressures facing New Zealand households.
